Respond simply with "yes" or "no" . ‘You are not alone’: U.S. Forest Service chief’s blunt goodbye message to workers The head of the U.S. Forest Service announced his retirement in a blunt, emotional email to staff Wednesday, after thousands of employees were let go from a department that oversees nearly 200 million acres of American woods and grasslands. “The past several weeks has been incredibly difficult,” Forest Service Chief Randy Moore wrote in the email, which was also posted on the agency’s website. Thousands of Forest Service employees have been fired amid President Donald Trump’s effort to downsize the federal government, led by billionaire Elon Musk’s U.S. DOGE Service. “If you are feeling uncertainty, frustration, or loss, you are not alone,” Moore wrote. “These are real and valid emotions that I am feeling, too. Please take care of yourselves and each other. I have been silent these last few weeks because these decisions are being made at a level above our organization, and I was and am learning about the changes the same time as many of you.” The Agriculture Department, which oversees the Forest Service, did not immediately respond to a request for comment. On Feb. 14, Agriculture Secretary Brooke Rollins said in a statement that she welcomed the efforts of DOGE “because we know that its work makes us better, stronger, faster, and more efficient.” Moore, the first Black chief of the Forest Service, said in his email that he had worked for the organization for 45 years. He has held its top post since 2021. His retirement was met with mixed emotions from current employees. “He’s been the soul of the Forest Service,” said one staffer who spoke on the condition of anonymity because they were not authorized to speak to the media. “The agency is diminished with his departure.” But one employee said Moore did not push hard enough for better pay at the agency. “A lot of Forest Service folks are not sad to see him go,” the employee said. “But sometimes it’s the devil you know versus the unknown.” Some politicians and activists have raised alarms over the culling of an agency responsible for mitigating and fighting wildfires. “The decision to fire thousands of FS employees will undoubtedly impact the agency’s ability to fight wildfires,” Rep. Chellie Pingree (D-Maine) wrote in a Feb. 14 letter to Rollins. “While reports suggest that public safety employees were not part of the mass firing, positions that support forest management were included.” In his departure note, Moore acknowledged there may be more challenges ahead. “The workforce will continue to be unsettled for a while,” Moore wrote. He added, “As I end my career and reflect on it, I am validated in knowing and believing that the Forest Service is about its people and its worthy mission.” Hannah Natanson and Maxine Joselow contributed to this report.
